chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Assessment
chapter.summary: Covers the assessment of people with dyspnoea in a palliative care setting, in order to determine the cause of dyspnoea and manage the person appropriately.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Prevalence of dyspnoea in palliative care

subChapters.htmlHeader: What questions should I ask about dyspnoea?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ask about:
    • Features of the dyspnoea (for example severity, timing, onset, and precipitating and exacerbating factors).
    • Associated physical symptoms (for example cough, sputum, haemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, pleuritic pain, fatigue, and panic).
    • Associated psychological symptoms (such as anxiety).
    • Precipitating or exacerbating factors (for example physical activity, posture, environmental factors [such as pollen], and emotional factors [such as anxiety, excitement, fear]).
    • Drug history (for example nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, beta-blockers, chemotherapy).
    • Quality of life issues (for example effect of the dyspnoea on the person's mobility, usual role, coping strategies [behavioural and emotional], and social interaction).
    • Progression of dyspnoea over time.
  • Dyspnoea can be difficult to quantify. Use of a visual analogue scale may be helpful in the initial assessment of severity and monitoring of response to treatment.
    • The person marks how breathless they feel on a line which has at one end 'no breathlessness' and at the other end 'maximum breathlessness'.
  • Questions which can be asked to help elicit the functional impact of dyspnoea include:
    • Does it disturb sleep?
    • Does it occur at rest?
    • Does it interfere with normal conversation?
    • Does it occur with washing or dressing?
    • How far can you walk on the flat without stopping for a rest?
    • How many stairs can you climb without stopping?
    • Are there things you cannot do because of breathlessness?
  • For more information, see Historical features suggesting a diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features from the clinical history suggesting a specific diagnosis
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Table 2. Typical symptoms associated with dyspnoea and possible diagnoses. Note: atypical presentations are common.

No chest pain, no cough or wheeze

Central, non-pleuritic chest pain

Lateralized pleuritic chest pain

Cough or wheeze, but no pain

Pulmonary embolismMyocardial infarctionPneumoniaAsthma
PneumothoraxMassive pulmonary embolismPulmonary embolismChronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Hypovolaemic shockPericardial effusionRib fracture-
Metabolic acidosis-Pneumothorax-
Acute left ventricular failure/pulmonary oedema---
Data from: [Devereux and Douglas, 2009]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion from medical and palliative care textbooks [Booth and Dudgeon, 2006; Devereux and Douglas, 2009; Chan, 2015; Regnard, 2010].

subChapters.fullItemName: What to look for on examination
subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I look for on examination?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Perform an appropriate examination for the stage of the person's illness, to attempt to determine the cause of the dyspnoea. This should include:
    • A general examination which may reveal pallor (suggestive of anaemia) or plethora and engorged veins of the neck and chest area (suggestive of superior vena cava obstruction).
    • Examination of the person's respiratory and cardiovascular systems.
    • Assessment of the effectiveness of the person's breathing (for example depth of breathing and expectoration of secretions).
    • Looking for features of panic or hyperventilation.
  • If appropriate, observe the person walking a set distance or carrying out a set task.
  • For more information, see Examination findings suggesting a diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Examination findings suggesting a diagnosis
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Table 3. Typical findings associated with dyspnoea and possible diagnoses:

 

Chest expansion

Percussion note

Breath sounds

Added sounds

Pleural effusionReduced on affected sideStony dull on affected sideAbsent or decreasedNone
ConsolidationReduced on affected sideDull on affected sideBronchialCrepitations
Collapse with bronchial obstructionReduced on affected sideDull on affected sideAbsent or decreasedNone
Upper airway obstructionReducedNo difference between sides of the chestDepends on the severity of the obstructionStridor
PneumothoraxReducedHyper-resonant on side of pneumothoraxAbsent or decreasedNone
COPD/asthmaMay be symmetrically decreasedNo difference between sides of the chestMay be normal, but silent chest in severe asthmaWheeze
PanicNormalNormalNormalNone
Acidosis*NormalNormalNormalNone
Heart failureNormal, or may be signs of pleural effusionNormal, or may be signs of pleural effusionNormal, or may be signs of pleural effusionBasal crepitations
Respiratory muscle weakness†ReducedNormalNormalNone
COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. * The breathing pattern in a person with acidosis is typically deep and rapid.† In people with respiratory muscle weakness, a paradoxical breathing pattern may be observed.

Data from: [Devereux and Douglas, 2009; Chan, 2015; Hopkin, 2010]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion from medical and palliative care literature [Twycross et al, 2009; Devereux and Douglas, 2009; Chan, 2015; Hopkin, 2010].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I investigate dyspnoea in palliative care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Investigations should be guided by the:
    • Clinical assessment.
    • Stage of disease and prognosis.
    • Risk-to-benefit ratio of the investigation.
    • Wishes of the person and their family.
  • The most useful investigations to consider in all people with non-acute dyspnoea in a palliative care situation in primary care include:
    • Full blood count (to exclude anaemia).
    • Pulse oximetry, if available (to assess hypoxia).
    • Chest radiography (to assess lung disease and heart failure).
    • Spirometry (to assess possible undiagnosed chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, however, spirometry can be difficult for people with cancer due to pain).
    • Electrocardiography (to exclude arrhythmia).
  • More information on investigation of non-malignant causes of dyspnoea is found in the CKS topics on Asthma, Chest infections - adult, Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and Heart failure - chronic.
  • In secondary care, further investigations may be requested, such as:
    • Computed tomography of the chest.
    • Investigations including Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) to rule out pulmonary embolism, if suspected.
    • Ultrasonography to exclude pleural effusion.
    • Echocardiography, to assess cardiac function.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on palliative care guidelines [International Association for Hospice and Palliative Care, 2013] and expert opinion from the palliative care literature [Booth and Dudgeon, 2006; Twycross et al, 2009; Chan, 2015].
